form.definition: noun or n is the fourteenth letter of the English alphabet.

dictionary.entry: N abbreviation for words that start with the letter 'n', such as north and noun. ... NOTEthat sometimes this abbreviation appears as n.

form.definition: abbreviation for not applicable or not available.

1 verb If someone nags you, they speak to you again and again because they want you to do something. They complain and find fault with you. Don't nagI've said I'll do it next week. The kids are nagging us for a better computer. Mum was nagging about the state of my bedroom again.
verb If something, such as a doubt or suspicion, nags at you, you can't get it out of your mind. I can't think of the name of the book. It's been nagging at me all day.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective nagging ...a dull, nagging pain.[qr

dictionary.entry:
nailnEIl
noun Nails are long, thin pieces of metal with one pointed end. You use them to join together pieces of wood by hitting them through the two layers of wood with a hammer.
verb If you nail one thing to another, you join them together by hammering nails through them both. She nailed the notice to the tree. You'd better nail the carpet down at the edge. They'll steal anything that isn't nailed down.
noun Your nails are the tough, horny parts on the end of your fingers and toes. Don't bite your nails. Her nails were painted a bright red.

form.definition: adjective If someone is naive, they are too trusting. They believe what they are told, or accept the way things seem to be, without wondering whether or not it's true. Don't be naivehe's trying to sell you rubbish. Each advertisement brings in thousands of dollars from naive readers.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb naively

form.definition: adjective If you are naked, you are not wearing any clothes. I prefer to sleep naked in summer. His naked body was found in a ditch.
adjective If something is naked, it is quite open and obvious and no attempt is made to hide it. She looked at him with naked contempt. ...naked aggression.
noun A name is what a particular person or place is called. My name is Wun Sei Chung. They trade under the name of Fox and Sons. She doesn't use her husband's name.

verb If you name someone or something, you give them a name. We named our dog Elsie. I was named after my great aunt. The new colony was named Victoria in honour of the Queen of England. c noun The name of something is the word we use to refer to it. What's the name of that purple flower? Is there a name for those plastic things you tie up the garbage sacks with? 'Casserole' is just a fancy name for a stew.

noun If you have a name for something, you have the reputation of being good at it or you are well known for doing it. He has a name for being a fast worker. She's made a name for herself as an architect.

verb If you name someone or something, you mention their name or reveal who they are. Can you name all the state capitals? I still need replies from Sacha, Suporn and Rochelle, to name just a few. The inquiry into police corruption named several senior officers.
noun A nap is a short sleep during the day. He always has a nap after lunch. Why don't you take a nap for half an hour?
noun The nap of a fabric is the fuzzy bits of fibre that lie above the surface.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb nap (naps, napped, napping)

form.definition: noun A napkin is a square piece of cloth or absorbent paper which people wipe their hands and mouth with if these get dirty or sticky when they are eating.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is serviette.[qr

dictionary.entry:
nappy`nApi:nappies
noun A nappy is a piece of absorbent material which a baby wears around its bottom until it has learnt to use the toilet. Some nappies are made of washable material, but most people buy disposable ones from the supermarket or chemist.

form.definition: noun A narcotic is a drug that eases pain and makes you sleepy. Narcotics are addictive and they are commonly used illegally.
noun Narration is the telling of a story, especially the spoken commentary of a documentary or a story on film.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun narrator verb narrate

form.definition: noun A narrative is the story of something that happened. He bored us with a long narrative about his accident. I like novels with strong characters and a fast narrative.

dictionary.entry:
narrow`nAr@Unarrowernarrowest 1a adjective If something is narrow, the distance from one side of it to the other is not great. We turned into a narrow lane. The garden consisted of a couple of flower beds and a narrow
verb If something narrows, it becomes less wide. The opposite of this is widen. The gap between the front two runners is narrowing.[qr Her eyes narrowed with suspicion.
adjective If someone has narrow beliefs, opinions, or views, they have a very limited way of looking at things.
... ANOTHER WORD for this is narrow-minded.
adjective A narrow result is one in which someone only just succeeds or fails. It could easily have turned out the other way. He was elected by a narrow margin. I had a narrow escapefive minutes later and I'd have been dead. ... WORD FAMILYadverb narrowly He narrowly missed winning his big race.

form.definition: adjective In medical or technical language, nasal refers to the nose. This spray will help to clear the nasal passages.
adjective If someone has a nasal voice, they make speech sounds using the air in their nose as well as their mouth. Some American accents sound very nasal. He spoke with a high, nasal tone.

adjective If someone is nasty, they are unpleasant and unkind to other people. What a nasty rude man! He's the nastiest boss I've ever worked for. I apologised at once, but she was very nasty about it.

adjective If something is nasty, it is unpleasant or you think it might have a seriously bad effect. There's a nasty smell in here. The weather's been pretty nasty lately. That's a nasty bruise! The news came as a nasty surprise.
noun A nation is an independent country. The last decade has seen many new nations emerge. The flags of over fifty nations fly outside the building.
noun A nation is made up of all the people of one country who live there. The Prime Minister gave an address to the nation.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun nationality (nationalities) 'What nationality are you?' 'I'm Australian.'

form.definition: adjective If something is national, it relates to the whole country. The Prime Minister intends to introduce national legislation in this area. ...a matter of national importance.
noun An Australian, U.S., Greek or other national is a citizen of Australia, the U.S.A., Greece or so on. Most overseas nationals require a visa to enter Australia.

national anthem A country's national anthem is a song or piece of music that has been officially chosen as a symbol of that country. It is played on public occasions, for example at sports matches between teams from different countries. Australia's national anthem is 'Advance Australia Fair'.
National Party The National Party is an Australian political party.

verb If a government nationalises a factory or an industry, it takes it away from private owners and runs it as part of the state system. ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is nationalize. ... WORD FAMILYnoun nationalisation (<or nationalization)
noun Nationalism is love for your country and pride in it.
noun Nationalism is the desire to form a nation of your own instead of being part of another country.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun nationalist

form.definition: adjective Your native town or country is the place where you were born. Sometimes I still miss my native village.
noun Someone who is a native of a certain country has lived there since they were born.
adjective If something is native to a particular area or country, it originally comes from there. Choose native Australian plants, which require less watering.
native speaker noun If you are a native speaker of a language, you have known it since you first learned to speak as a child. Talking with native speakers will improve your fluency.

verb In informal language, if you say someone natters about something, you mean they talk about it for a long time in a relaxed way. She can natter on the phone for hours. Once he and his mates start nattering about football it's hard to stop them.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun natter We had a good natter about old times.

form.definition: adjective In informal language, if you say something is natty, you mean it is smart and neat. He's a natty dresser. She's got a natty little computer that fits in her pocket.
adjective Something that is natural is normal. It is what you would expect. He's suffering from chronic fatigue, not just natural tiredness. It's only natural that you're upset.

adjective If something such as behaviour or a certain skill is natural, you were born with it and you did not need to learn it. She has a natural talent for singing. Toddlers display a natural curiosity about the world that we lose as we grow older.
adjective Natural surroundings or physical features are not artificial or created by people. We sheltered in a natural harbour. It's an area of outstanding natural beauty. She's a natural blonde.

4 adjective If you say that someone is natural or behaves in a natural way, you mean that they behave in a relaxed and simple way without any pretence. She's a really natural personyou'll like her straight away.
a natural If you say someone is a natural at doing something, you mean they do it very well, sometimes without having been taught. He's a natural at tennisif he practised no-one could ever beat him.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb naturally Naturally, you'll want some time to think it over. Naturally he was angry when he lost his job.

form.definition: adjective If migrants are naturalised, they have become citizens of their new country. I was born in Korea, and now I'm a naturalised Australian citizen.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is naturalized. ... WORD FAMILYverb naturalise

form.definition: noun Nature is everything in the world that was not made or constructed by people. I'm sick of city lifeI want to get back to nature.
noun A person's nature is their character or the way they behave. She has a very gentle nature. It's not in his nature to bear grudges.

noun The nature of something is its basic characteristics or qualities. The nature of the phenomenon is not yet clear. The soil is of a dry, sandy nature. It's in the nature of paper to gradually deteriorate. ...discoveries of a technical nature.

better nature Your better nature is your conscience, or the nicer side of your personality. It wasn't really convenient, but my better nature made me help them out. It's no use appealing to her better nature, she's completely heartless.

second nature If behaving in a certain way is second nature to you, you do it automatically, without thinking. The computer system was a pain to learn at first, but now it's second nature. After living in Jakarta for five years, speaking Indonesian comes as second nature to me.
adjective We say children are naughty when they behave badly and don't do what they are told. Don't be naughty! Put it back at once!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun naughtiness

form.definition: noun Nausea is the feeling of being sick in your stomach. When you suffer from nausea, you feel as if you are going to vomit.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective nauseous I often felt nauseous when I was pregnant.

form.definition: noun Your navel is the small round hollow in the middle of your abdomen.
form.note: ... SEE THE PICTUREat body. ... DO NOT CONFUSEthis word with naval, which is the adjective from navy.

form.definition: verb If you navigate while you are travelling in a vehicle, you look at a map and work out which direction you should take to get where you want. You drive and I'll navigate. Sailors used to navigate by the stars, but now they have sophisticated electronic aids.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun navigation

form.definition: noun A country's navy is part of its armed forces. It is made up of ships with sailors who are trained to fight at sea or to defend the country's coast.
noun Navy is also a very dark blue colour, so dark that it is almost black. This colour is also called navy blue.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective naval ...a naval battle. ...a naval uniform.< >adjective navy or navy blue ...a navy blue skirt. ...a white shirt with navy stripes.

form.definition: abbreviation for the Latin words nota bene, which mean 'note well'. This is used in written language, to point out something that is particularly important or perhaps surprising. The meeting will begin at 10.00 (NB not 10.30 as usual).
abbreviation for north-east.

dictionary.entry:
nearnI@ (adjective and adverb forms nearer, nearest
preposition If something is near someone or something else, it is close to it in place, in time, or in some other way. I parked near the school. 'Where's Geelong?' 'It's near Melbourne.' The restaurant gets very busy near midday. The building is near collapse.
adverb If something is near in relation to something else, it is only a short distance away. I'll go there on footI live quite near. He beckoned her nearer.
adjective If something is said to be near, it is not far away in place or time. It's polite to take the nearest piece, not the biggest. There's unlikely to be any improvement in the near future.
adjective Your near relatives are the ones who are most closely related to you, for example your parents and brothers and sisters rather than all your cousins. Is there any history of heart trouble among your near relatives?
verb If you near something, you get close to it. As the plane neared the city, we could see the lights below us. He must be nearing fifty. Pollution has neared record levels this week.

form.definition: adverb If something is nearby, it is close to where you are or to something mentioned. Excuse me, is there a post office nearby? Fortunately there was a service station nearby when we ran out of petrol. He waited nearby in case we needed help.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective nearby The restaurant's BYO, so let's pop into a nearby bottle shop.

form.definition: adverb If something nearly happens, it almost happens but doesn't actually do so. If something is nearly ready, nearly perfect and so on, then it is almost in that state but not quite. I ran all the way and still nearly missed the bus. The cloth is very dark, nearly black. I didn't get back till nearly midnight. 'Have you finished yet?' 'Nearly.'

not nearly In informal language, you use not nearly to emphasise that something is certainly not the case. I haven't nearly finished packing yet! The new album's not nearly as good as her last one. I don't like him nearly as much as our last teacher.

adjective If someone is neat, they are tidy in their habits and careful about their appearance. Frieda was always so neat, but my side of the room was a complete mess. We were greeted by rows of neat children in uniform.

adjective If something is neat, it is tidy and in good order. My bedroom never seems to stay neat for long. The clothes were all arranged in neat piles. Her hair was tied back in a neat plait. You've got very neat writing.

adjective In informal language, if you say something is neat, you mean that it is very clever or efficient or you like it very much. Hey, that's a neat idea! I've discovered a neat way of making the program run faster. Her new car's really neat.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun neatness < >adverb neatly

form.definition: adjective If something is necessary, you need it. Before you begin, check you have all the necessary ingredients. Is an umbrella really necessary in January?
adjective If it is necessary to do something, it is important that you do it. It is necessary to clean the filter every three months. Is it necessary to fill in a separate form for each person?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun necessity (necessities) They lack even such necessities as food and shelter. adverb necessarily You will not necessarily have to attend an interview.

form.definition: noun Your neck is the part of your body that joins your head to your shoulders. It forms part of your spine.
form.note: ... SEE THE PICTUREat body.

form.definition: noun The neck of something such as a bottle is the narrowest part of it.

neck and neck If two competitors are neck and neck, you can't tell which of them will win because at the moment they are doing equally well. The two horses were neck and neck at the first bend. At the moment we're neck and neck with our main rivals.
noun A necklace is a piece of jewellery which you wear around your neck.

adjective Nee is a French word which means 'born'. It can be used in written language after a woman's surname to indicate a different surname she had before she was married. ...Christine White, nee Thomas.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is n;aaee.

form.definition: verb If you need something, you must have it in order to succeed in what you are doing. I need a ruler to draw these lines straight. We need some more sugarwe've almost run out. This razor needs a new blade. Do you need a hand with that?
verb If you need something, you require it as a basic necessity of life. Humans need water to survive. We all need to feel we belong.

verb If you need to do something, or if something needs to be done, it is important that it is done. I need to leave at four to go to the dentist. Mummy, I need to go to the toilet! The agenda needs to be decided before the meeting.

in need If someone is in need of something, they are in difficulty because they haven't got it. I'm in need of several thousand dollars to pay my debts. Are you in need of a lift? I'm going that way. ...a charity to help those in need.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun need ...a basic need to be loved. ...our company's needs for the future.< >adjective needy (needier, neediest) ...a collection for needy victims of the bush fires.[qr

dictionary.entry:
needle`ni:dl
noun You use a needle for sewing. It is a long and very thin piece of metal with one sharp end and a hole in the other end. You thread cotton through the hole so that it is left behind when you push the needle through fabric and out again.
noun Knitting needles are a pair of long needles used for knitting by hand. They are usually made of plastic or metal, and are about twenty centimetres long. You hold one in each hand and transfer the knitting from one to the other as you knit.
noun A needle is also a pointer on a measuring instrument such as a compass dial or a speedometer.
noun The needle of a syringe is the pointed tip that pierces the skin when a doctor injects drugs or takes a blood sample.
noun In informal language, if you say that a doctor gives you a needle, you mean that they give you an injection.

form.definition: adjective A negative answer to a question or suggestion is one that says 'no'. She got a totally negative response to her idea. So far I've had six negative replies and four have said they can come.
noun A negative is an answer which means 'no'. The reply to our question was a clear negative.

adjective Someone who is negative is inclined to look on the bad side of things. They are not cheerful or hopeful, but expect that things will go wrong or get worse. Don't be so negative! Let's think how we could make it work. Her negative attitude really gets me down.
noun In photography, a negative is a picture in which the light and dark parts are reversed. The film in a camera records images as negatives, from which positive prints are made.
adjective In maths, a negative value is one which is less than zero. It is written with a minus sign in front of the number.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is positive.

form.definition: verb If you neglect something, you don't pay as much attention to it as you ought to. He neglected his studies, and so failed his exams.
verb If you neglect someone or something, you don't look after them properly. The children were neglected for days at a time while the couple went out drinking. I've neglected the garden for months.

verb In formal language, if you neglect to do something, you fail to do it. You don't do it, probably because you have forgotten about it or don't know that you should do it. I'm afraid I neglected to feed the cat this morning. Several students neglected to hand in their assignments on time.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun neglect The buildings are suffering from neglect.

form.definition: noun A negligee is a woman's dressing gown that is very flimsy and feminine in style. Francine was wearing her sexy black negligee.
adjective If someone is negligent, they don't take enough care over what they are supposed to be doing. She has been negligent in her duties. He was charged with negligent driving.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun negligence

form.definition: adjective If something is negligible, it is so small or slight that it is hardly worth considering. The impact of this price rise on the inflation rate will be negligible. There has been negligible improvement since I complained.

adjective If something is negotiable, it is not definitely fixed, but can be revised as a result of discussion and negotiation. The salary is negotiable, according to the experience of the candidate appointed. Our demands are not negotiable.
not negotiable If not negotiable is written on a cheque, it must be deposited in an account. You cannot get cash for it.

verb If you negotiate with somebody, you have a discussion together and try to come to an agreement, for example about buying or selling something, or the wages and conditions for a job. The union is still negotiating with management about the wage claim. I hope to negotiate a much better price.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See negotiable. noun negotiation The strike was called off as negotiations continued.noun negotiator

form.definition: noun Your neighbours are the people who live near you. We invited all the neighbours to the party. The cat belongs to our next-door neighbour.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is neighbor. ... WORD FAMILYnoun neighbourhood The whole neighbourhood was woken by the explosion.

form.definition: conjunction You use neither when there are two (or more) parts to what you are saying, and both (or all) the parts are negative. Neither Gill nor Ben came to the party. I'm not going, neither is Sally. 'I don't like this soup.' 'Me neither.'

pronoun You use neither to refer to two items when you are making a negative statement about them both. Neither of the girls wanted to go. I had to return both disksneither would work. 'Do you like the red one or the black one?' 'NeitherI prefer the green.'
noun Your nephew is the son of your sister or brother, or the son of your spouse's sister or brother.
form.note: ... THE FEMININE FORMof this is niece.

form.definition: <noun> In informal language, a nerd is an idiot.
noun A nerve is one of the long thin fibres in your body which carry messages between your brain and your body. These messages control your movement and your sense of touch.

noun Your nerve is the courage you have to do something dangerous or difficult. He's going to sing at the concertI hope his nerve doesn't fail him. I've been working up the nerve to ask my boss for a rise. She's got a nerve wanting the date changed again.

get on your nerves In informal language, if you say someone or something gets on your nerves, you mean they are very irritating. Her continual whinging really gets on my nerves. 4 nerves Your nerves are your ability to cope with pressure and stress. I asked the doctor for something to calm my nerves. Her nerves have been bad since her husband died, poor thing. ... WORD FAMILYadjective nervy When I haven't had enough sleep I get nervy and irritable.
adjective If you are nervous, you are anxious or worried about what will happen. I was really nervous before the interview, but it went fine. My dentist is very good with nervous patients.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun nervously He looked nervously about him. 'I'm not sure', she said nervously.< >noun nervousness

form.definition: noun A nest is a home that a bird builds out of twigs and leaves.
noun Other animals, such as rabbits, turtles and some insects, also build nests to use as their homes.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb nest There's a magpie nesting in the gum tree in our yard.

form.definition: noun Net is a fabric which has large gaps between the fibres so that you can see through it. It is used to make veils and curtains. Another word for this is netting. The bride's veil was white net with flowers sewn on it.

noun A net is a bag with holes in it that is used to catch fish. It can be either a small one on the end of a stick that you use in a river or stream, or a very large one that is thrown over the side of a ship at sea. b noun In tennis, volleyball and some other games, the net is the barrier in the centre of the court over which you have to hit the ball.
adjective In business, a net profit or loss is the amount that is left after all the expenses have been paid. Another spelling for this is nett. The opposite of this is gross.
adjective The net effect or result of something is the most important effect or result, without taking any notice of the details. The net result of the meeting was that the project was cancelled.

adjective The net weight of something is its actual weight, not including the weight of the packaging. Another spelling for this is nett. The opposite of this is gross. The net weight of this can of tomatoes is 325 grams.
noun Netball is a game in which two teams of seven players try to score goals by throwing a large round ball through a ring on the top of a pole.
noun A nettle is a weed which has long spiky leaves which sting if you touch them. 2 verb If you nettle someone, you annoy and irritate them. Don't let her nettle youjust ignore her.

noun A network is made up of a number of lines or routes that connect and form a system. The connections give access to the various parts of the system. There is a network of tunnels under the city. My computer is connected to the office network.

noun A network is a collection of people, groups or companies which are connected because of their work or common interests. He started a support network for AIDS sufferers. Many people find out about jobs through their network of friends and acquaintances.
noun A network is a group of radio or TV stations in different areas of a country which share programs for broadcasting.

adjective We say someone is neurotic if we think they can't stop thinking about something or if they worry too much. Roula's quite neurotic about her weight. Don't be so neuroticwe've got plenty of time.
adjective If something is neuter, it is neither masculine nor feminine. In German, all nouns are either masculine, feminine, or neuter.
adjective If a person or country remains neutral in a dispute or war, they do not support one side or the other. Switzerland was neutral in World War II.
adjective If someone remains neutral in a discussion or debate, they do not enter into the argument. They remain impartial. Rhoda took a neutral position in the discussion.

adjective If someone's voice is neutral, they speak without emotion. They don't sound as if they are upset or angry or surprised. 'Really?' he said, in a neutral voice. I tried to keep my tone neutral.
noun If a car or vehicle is in neutral, its engine power is not being transmitted to the wheels. The car has to be put into gear before it can be driven.
noun The neutral wire is one of the three wires in household electrical cords. It is covered in blue rubber, or black in older cords. See also earth and live.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun neutrality

form.definition: adverb Never means 'not at any time', or 'not in any circumstances'. It may refer to the past or to the future. I've never eaten kangaroo meat. I'll never forget that holiday!

adverb In formal language, nevertheless means 'even so' or 'all the same'. You use it at the beginning of a sentence to emphasise a contrast to what you said before. He was sick on Wednesday. Nevertheless, he still went to work. She's had problems at home. Nevertheless, her behaviour is not acceptable.

adjective If something is new, it has only just come into existence. Most people can't afford to buy a new car, so they get a second-hand one. He lives in one of those new houses by the river. The neighbours came to see the new baby.

adjective If something is new, it is a change from what there has been before. This car's beyond repairI'll have to get a new one. I'm starting a new job next week. Why don't you try something new for dinner?

adjective If you are new to a place or a situation, you haven't been in it for long. I remember when I was new to Australia, I was struck by the open spaces. 'Can you show me how the photocopier works?' 'I'm sorry, I'm new here myself.'
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun newness

form.definition: noun News is information about something that has just happened. Have you heard the news? Otto's won the lottery! I'm afraid I've got some bad news for you. I haven't got much newseverything's much the same as before.

noun News is information in the newspapers and on the TV and radio about important events that have just happened around the world. There's never any news in the papers these daysit's all ads! 'This is the ABC News, read by Barrie Freedman.'[bn--newsagent noun A newsagent is ashop which sells newspapers and magazines. Usually they also sell things such as stationery, confectionery and cigarettes.[ql
noun A newspaper is a daily or weekly publication that prints the latest news, as well as articles of general interest, and advertisements.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this, especially in informal language, is paper.

form.definition: adjective The next time or occasion is the one immediately following. I arrived on the 3rd, and left the next day. Next morning it had gone. I'm looking forward to his next book. I'll know better next time. She turned to serve the next customer.
adjective The next place is the closest or nearest. Rasha is in the next room. There's a doctor in the next village.
adverb If something happens next, it happens immediately after something else. I'll do the washing first, and next the ironing. What shall we do next? Next you'll be saying it was all my fault.
next to If you're next to something, you're beside it. Siri's the one standing next to the window. There's a florist next to the post office. I sat down next to Anwar.

dictionary.entry: next of kinnEkst@v`kInnextofkin noun In formal language, especially in official documents, your closest relative is referred to as your next of kin. Police will not release the names of the victims until next of kin have been notified.[qr

nibnIb
noun The nib of a fountain pen is the part that you write with, where the ink comes out.

form.definition: verb If you nibble something or nibble at something, you eat it in little bits. She hardly ate anythingjust nibbled a few vegetables. The woodwork looked as if it had been nibbled by mice.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun nibble

form.definition: adjective If something is nice it is attractive, pleasant or agreeable. That's a nice dressis it new? Did you have a nice time at the beach? It must be nice to live so close to the sea. 'Would you like a cup of tea?' 'That'd be nice.'

adjective If you say that someone is nice, you mean that you like them because they are friendly and kind. Our new teacher is very nice. When I explained the reason for the delay, she was very nice about it. Be nice to Paulhe seems to be upset about something.

adjective A nice plan or idea is one that solves a problem, or is exactly what you need. Janice came up with a nice solution. 'Why don't we go to the beach first, then back here for a beer and on to a meal?' 'Nice one, let's do that!'
nice to have met you People sometimes say nice to have met you when they are saying goodbye to someone they've just met for the first time.
nice to meet you People sometimes say nice to meet you as a greeting when they meet someone for the first time.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb nicely noun niceness

form.definition: noun A niche is a hollow recess in a wall.
noun A niche is a suitable or appropriate position for someone. Gyorgi's really found his niche, working at the local library.
verb If you nick yourself, you cut yourself slightly. He nicked himself with the razor. b noun A nick is a small cut.
verb In informal language, if you say someone nicks something, you mean they steal it. He nicked $5 out of my purse.

in good nick In informal language, if you say that someone or something is in good nick, you mean that they are very healthy or in good condition. I'm in pretty good nick for my age. This car's a beautyit's in really good nick.
in the nick of time In informal language, if you say something happens in the nick of time, you mean it happens at the last possible moment. I managed to stop in the nick of time.
nick off In informal language, if you nick off, you leave without telling anyone. <He nicked off before I could catch him>.
nick out In informal language, if you nick out, you go somewhere for a short time. <She's just nicked out to the post office>.
A nickname is an affectionate, informal name for someone, often used by close friends or relatives.
noun Nicotine is an addictive substance found in tobacco.
noun Your niece is the daughter of your sister or brother, or the daughter of your spouse's sister or brother.
form.note: ... THE MASCULINE FORMof this is nephew.

form.definition: adjective In informal language, if you say someone or something is nifty, you mean you think they are very smart or clever. You should watch him workhe's very nifty at selling things. This calculator's got some really nifty features.
adjective You say something is nifty, in informal language, if you think it is stylish. She was wearing a nifty blue outfit. That red stripe makes it look really nifty.
noun Night is the period of darkness between sunset and sunrise. She stayed out all night. I was woken up in the middle of the night by a loud crash.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is day.

form.definition: noun You can also use night to refer to the evening, particularly as a time for social activities. Did you see the movie last night? Let's go out for a drink one night next week. ... WORD FAMILYadverb nightly Two shows nightly8.00 and 9.30.
<plural noun> Nightclothes are clothes to wear in bed.
<noun> A nightdress is a loose dress to wear in bed. An informal word for this is <nightie>.
noun A nightshirt is a long shirt to wear in bed.

noun A nightmare is a frightening dream. I've been having terrible nightmares lately. Eating cheese is supposed to give you nightmares. ...a recurring nightmare about being chased through a dark forest.

noun If you say an experience or situation is a nightmare, you mean that it is very unpleasant or difficult. The trip home was a nightmarethe kids were sick and the car broke down! Sorting out the files she'd left behind was a real nightmare.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective nightmarish ...a nightmarish landscape of twisted branches.

form.definition: noun Nil is another word for nothing or zero. The final score was two-nil in our favour. We'll never reduce the road toll to nil.
adjective If someone is nimble, they are light on their feet and able to move quickly. The youngest and most nimble of the acrobats climbed the human pyramid. I'm still pretty nimble for my age.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun nimbleness

form.definition: noun Nine is the number 9, eight plus one. There were nine of us altogetherfar too many to fit into the car.
adjective If you have nine things, the number of things you have amounts to nine. There are only nine balloons in the box. Who's taken the other ones?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See ninth.

form.definition: noun Nineteen is the number 19, ten plus nine. Twenty-five started the race, but only nineteen finished.
adjective If you have nineteen things, the number of things you have amounts to nineteen. There are nineteen people in our English class.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See nineteenth.

form.definition: adjective The nineteenth person or thing is the one that comes in order after the eighteenth. Elsa came nineteenth in the marathon.
noun A nineteenth is also one of nineteen parts. We'll get a nineteenth each.
noun Ninety is the number 90, ten lots of nine. We can accommodate parties of up to ninety.
adjective If you have ninety things, the number of things you have amounts to ninety. I've got ninety pages to read stillI want to finish it today.
nineties The nineties in the twentieth century is the decade from 1990 to 1999, in the eighteenth century from 1880 to 1889 and so on.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective ninetieth

form.definition: adjective The ninth person or thing is the one that comes in order after the eighth. Pearson Street is the ninth street on your left after you turn onto the highway.
noun A ninth is also one of nine parts. I sliced the cake into rather uneven ninths.

verb In informal language, you say you nip over, across or down to somewhere if you are going there quickly and usually only for a short time. I'll just nip down to the shops for some bread. Can you nip over and see me after tea?
verb If an animal nips someone or something, it bites them lightly. The dog nipped my leg playfully.
noun A nip is also a small measure of alcohol. Irish coffee is coffee with a nip of whisky in it.
nip in the air In informal language, if you say that there is a nip in the air, you mean that is quite cold.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective nippy (nippier, nippiest) Take a coatit's quite nippy tonight.

form.definition: <plural noun> Nippers are junior lifesavers.
noun Nipples are the raised red or brown parts on a woman's breasts or a man's chest. Babies suck milk through their mother's nipples.
form.note: ... SEE THE PICTUREat body.

form.definition: noun A nit is the egg of a head louse, sometimes found in people's hair. There's an outbreak of nits in Tom's class, so we're all using a special shampoo.

adverb No is a negative response or exclamation. You use it to express denial or disagreement or refusal. The opposite of this is yes. 'Are you Mike?' 'No, I'm Steve.' We went on Mondayno, sorry, Tuesday.' 'Would you like another?' 'No, thank you.' No, don't do that. No, that can't be right.
adjective You use no before a noun or noun phrase to mean 'not any'. She has no living relatives. There's no soup left. I received no reply to my letter. No student attempted question three.
noun A no is a negative vote, or a refusal. When the motion was put to the vote, the noes carried it. My suggestion met with a firm no.
abbreviation for number. In reply, please quote Reference No. 3665.
adjective People say you are noble if you act honestly and in the interests of others, even if it may not be to your own advantage. That was very noble of you, to give up your place like that.
adjective Something described as noble belongs, or looks as if it belongs, to the . Apparently she's descended from one of the noble families of Europe.
noun A noble is someone who belongs to a high rank in society, by having a hereditary title.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb nobly noun nobility

form.definition: pronoun Nobody means 'not a single person'. Nobody likes losing their job. 'Who helped you?' 'NobodyI did it all by myself.' There was nobody in the room.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is no-one. You use these forms to refer to people, and nothing to refer to things.

form.definition: noun A nobody is somebody you consider to be unimportant and insignificant. The guy I'd overlooked as a complete nobody turned out to be the professor. We'll show them that they can't treat us like a bunch of nobodies!
adjective Animals that are nocturnal are usually active at night and sleep during the day.

dictionary.entry:
nodnOdnodsnoddednodding 1a verb If you nod, you move your head up and down. She nodded her head in agreement. He nodded to
noun A nod is a movement of your head. At a nod from the leader, they formed a circle around me.
nod off In informal language, if you say someone nods off you mean they fall asleep, especially if they're just dozing in the daytime. The meeting was so boring that I kept feeling myself nodding off.

form.definition: noun A nodule is a small round lump of something. You can get nodules on your vocal cords from too much loud singing. The weeds grow from nodules in the root system.
noun A noise is a sound. I'm sure I heard a noise in the kitchen. My car's making grating noises in first gear.
noun Noise is loud and unpleasant sound. The children were making a lot of noise. I can't concentrate with all this noise from the building site.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective noisy (noisier, noisiest) Life can be hell with noisy neighbours.< >adverb noisily

form.definition: verb If you nominate someone for an elected position, you put their name forward as a candidate. Each candidate must be nominated by a financial member.
verb If you nominate for an elected position, you put your own name forward as a candidate. I'll nominate for president next year, I think.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun nomination All nominations must be submitted by 1 July. noun nominee Do all the nominees consent to stand as candidates?

form.definition: adjective If someone is nonchalant, they are not worried or concerned about what is happening. I don't know how you can be so nonchalant about the interview. 'Of course', she replied, with a nonchalant smile. ... WORD FAMILYnoun nonchalance He looked about him with studied nonchalance.< >adverb nonchalantly He was leaning nonchalantly against the wall.

adjective If you say something is nondescript, you mean it is ordinary and uninteresting, without anything particularly notable about it. They live in a nondescript house on one of those new estates. Her dress was a nondescript green. The whole evening was fairly nondescript, really.
pronoun None means 'not one' or 'not any'. None of the jumpers fitted her. None of us likes him. 'How many have you eaten?' 'None.' I wanted some bread, but there was none left.

dictionary.entry: nonentitynOn`Ent@ti:nonentities noun If you call someone a nonentity, you think they're of no interest or importance. In the office Tibor was always a bit of a nonentity, but at the party he really blossomed. I'm not going to be told what to do by that little nonentity of a filing clerk.

form.definition: adverb Nonetheless is another word for nevertheless.
noun Nonfiction is factual writing about real people and events, rather than novels or stories. I love reading nonfiction, especially history and biography.
adjective If something is nonflammable, it does not catch fire easily.
adjective If you are nonplussed at something, you feel puzzled or confused and you aren't sure what to do about it. He looked rather nonplussed at this answer.

noun If you say someone is talking nonsense, you think that what they are saying has no meaning, or it is completely wrong or very stupid or irrelevant. He became delirious and started mumbling nonsense. 'I'll never pass the exam.' 'Nonsense, of course you will!' She started telling us a lot of nonsense about her family history.
noun Noodles are a type of pasta, cut into long thin strips.
noun In informal English, your noodle is your head or brain. That's a nasty bump on the noodlehow did you get it? Use your noodleof course he can't carry them all at once.
noun Noon is midday, 12 o'clock in the daytime. We'll try and finish the meeting by noon. The train leaves at five minutes to noon.
pronoun No-one means 'not a single person'.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is nobody.

form.definition: noun A noose is a rope with a loop in it that is secured by a sliding knot, so that the loop tightens when you pull the rope. Her body was discovered in the attic, hanging in a noose.
conjunction Nor is used after neither to mention something else that is also negative. Neither Tomoko nor Aisha came to the party.
conjunction Nor is used after a negative statement to introduce another negative. I don't want to go, nor does Meike. 'I'm not very hungry.' 'Nor am I.'

adjective If something is normal, it is usual or ordinary. I decided not to follow my normal routine, but to go to the park. A body temperature of 37 degrees is regarded as normal. It's only normal to feel resentment.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun normality At last the visitors left and things returned to normality.< >adverb normally I don't normally eat puddings, but this is a special treat.

form.definition: noun If you are facing east, the direction where the sun rises, the north is the direction on your left. The wind was blowing from the north.
noun The north of a country or region is the part which is most towards the north. He lives in the north of Australia, near Darwin.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEdirection is south. ... WORD FAMILYadjective north < >adverb north Keep travelling north. Our house faces due northwe get lots of winter sun.< >adjective northerly ...northerly winds. ...in a northerly direction.< >adjective northern ...Northern Territory.< >noun northerner He's a northerner, down from Queens-land for a month or so.< >adverb north Keep travelling north.

form.definition: adverb Northward means 'toward the north'. We headed northward for the next two hours.
noun The nose is the part of your body that you use to smell things. See the picture at body. Breathe in through your nose and out through your mouth.
noun Your sense of smell is sometimes called your nose. My nose tells me dinner's almost ready.

look down your nose In informal language, you say you look down your nose at someone if you treat them badly because you think that they are not as good as you are. I wish you'd be nicer to my friends and not look down your nose at them because they're not working.
If you nose forward, you move ahead slowly and carefully. He nosed forward cautiously through the fog until he felt the step in front of him.

pay through the nose In informal language, if you say you pay through the nose for something, you mean you pay a great deal of money for it. I persuaded him to rent me the flat, but I had to pay through the nose for it.

poke your nose into In informal language, if you say someone pokes their nose into something, you mean they get involved in something that doesn't have anything to do with them. He's always poking his nose into other people's business.

turn up your nose In informal language, you say you turn up your nose at something if you reject it because you think it's not good enough for you. She turned up her nose at the suggestion of borrowing my dress.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See nasal. adjective nosy (nosier, nosiest) Don't be so nosyit's none of your business.

form.definition: noun Nostalgia is an affectionate feeling for the past. I look back on my childhood with nostalgia.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective nostalgic I always feel nostalgic when I hear that song.

form.definition: noun Your nostrils are the two holes in your nose that you breathe through.
form.note: ... SEE THE PICTUREat body.

form.definition: adverb You use not in a sentence to show a negative or an opposite. I'm not happy. They did not return. He wouldn't leave. Don't you want to come? Do not touch the exhibits.
form.note: ... NOTEThis word is often used in a shortened form: wouldn't is short for would not; don't is short for do not.

form.definition: adverb You use not in the form n't as part of a question added on after a positive statement. It means that you are confident that the person you are talking to will agree with your statement. Your voice does not go up at the end. It's a nice day, isn't it? You liked that, didn't you?

adjective If something is notable, it is important or impressive. Governor Macquarie is one of the most notable figures in early Australian history. The area contains some notable scenery. Her speeches are notable for their humour.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb notably Barry was notably absent. She was in a notably good mood yesterday.

form.definition: noun A notch is a small sharp cut in something, especially on its edge. He carved a notch in the twig and wound the string round it. You can adjust the height of the deck chair by means of these notches at the back.
noun In informal language, a notch is a level or step on a scale. I was quite impressedshe went up a notch or two in my estimation. The picture's not very clearcan you turn the contrast up a notch?

noun A note is a short informal letter you write to someone. I've written her a note about the meeting next week. Several pupils were giggling and passing notes at the back of the class. I left a note on the door to say I'd be back at two.
noun A note is a written reminder of something. Have you made a note of the dates for the school play? Did you take notes at the meeting? Can I borrow your notes from Tuesday's class?
verb If you note something, you write it down as a record or reminder. I noted the correct answers in the margin. I should like my objection to be noted in the minutes.
verb If you note something, you are aware of it. You notice it. This is our latest model. Note the compact design and the digital display. I noted that she was looking very tired.
4 noun A note is a piece of paper money. Can you change a $50 note?
noun In music, a note is an individual sound, or the symbol used to represent it in writing. The last notes slowly died away. A dot after the note indicates that it's longer than the other one.

of note Someone or something of note is famous or is worth remembering. She's a woman of some note in our community. Nothing of note happened while you were away. ... WORD FAMILYadjective See notable. adjective noted She's noted for her caustic wit. He later became a noted politician.

noun You use nothing to refer to a complete absence. There's nothing in the box. We've nothing left to eat. He said nothing to me about it. I looked where she pointed, but saw nothing. Is there nothing I can do to get it back? 2 noun If you say somebody is a nothing, you mean they are of no importance. I'm fed up with being just a nothing in a huge organisation.

noun If you say that an event or an achievement is nothing, you mean that it is not very important or significant. 'Thanks for the lift.' 'Oh, it's nothing, I was coming this way anyway.' Huh, running ten kilometres is nothing, I could do twenty before breakfast!
for nothing If you do something for nothing, you do it free of charge. He fixed my bike for nothing, so I owe him a favour. If you buy a dozen, I'll throw in an extra one for nothing.

verb If you notice someone or something, you become aware of them. I noticed her at the back of the room. I'd never noticed the stain before. I couldn't help noticing you were upset. Did you notice what time he arrived?
noun A notice is written information about something, which is placed in a public spot for people to see. Did you see the notice about the garage sale on the telegraph pole?
noun A notice is also a formal public announcement of something, such as a birth, death or engagement. The death notice was in Saturday's paper.

noun Notice is also the amount of time between when you resign from a job or are dismissed and when you actually leave. I have to give a week's notice. I'm going to hand in my notice on Monday. My boss gave me two weeks' notice out of the blue.

take notice If you take notice of someone or something, you pay attention to them and act accordingly. Don't take any notice of Haroldhe's always so negative. I saw them waving frantically but took no notice. I wish I'd taken notice of her advice.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective noticeable

form.definition: verb If someone notifies you of something, they inform you about it, usually in a formal or official way. You will be notified of the date of the hearing within 14 days.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun notification You will receive official notification of the result.

form.definition: noun A notion is an idea that you have about something, especially one that is vague or inaccurate. He has the silly notion that Brisbane is only four hours' drive from Sydney.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective notional I've added a notional 10% for unexpected expenses.

form.definition: adjective If someone is notorious, they are famous or well known for something bad. ...the notorious Ned Kelly. She's a notorious liar. I'm notorious for leaving everything to the last minute.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is infamous. ... WORD FAMILYnoun notoriety

form.definition: noun Nought is the number 0, which represents zero. One million is written as one followed by six noughts.
noun Nouns are members of a class of words that includes the names of people and things. Mary, Melbourne, mountain and modesty are nouns in English.

verb If you nourish something, you feed it so that it can survive and grow. It is important to nourish the plants with fertiliser. There's not enough protein in it to nourish growing children. Her grandmother's tales nourished her imagination.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective nourishing ...a bowl of nourishing soup.< >noun nourishment Junk food contains little nourishment.

form.definition: abbreviation for November.
noun A novel is a long story in book form. He writes novels and short stories for children.

adjective If something is novel, it is new and different, and rather surprising. He came up with a novel analysis of the data. Let's try a novel approach to the problem. Her ideas are novel, to say the least!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See novelty. noun novelist

form.definition: noun Novelty is the quality of being new and different. I'm still enjoying the novelty of my new job. He became disillusioned when the novelty of the relationship wore off.
noun A novelty is something that is unusual or different. A white Christmas is a novelty if you're Australian. It'll be quite a novelty if he turns up on time.
noun Novelties are small cheap gifts that you hand out, especially to children at parties.
noun November is the eleventh month of the year.
adverb Now means 'at this moment' or 'at present'. I'm leaving now. Where are you working now? I want you to do it right now. I'll tell you when to push. Now!
now that Now that is used to indicate that something happens because a certain stage has been reached. Now that Sue's arrived, we can begin. She'll be starting school now that she's five.
adjective A noxious substance is poisonous. Clouds of noxious gas poured out of the ruptured container.
adjective If something is noxious, it is harmful or unpleasant. Our council has declared this a noxious weedwe're supposed to get rid of it. She offered me a glass of a noxious green liquid.[qr

dictionary.entry:
nozzle`nOzl
noun A nozzle is a plastic or metal piece fitted to the end of a hose to control the flow of water or other liquid that comes through.

form.definition: abbreviation for New South Wales.
abbreviation for Northern Territory.

adjective Nuclear weapons, such as atomic bombs, produce explosions created by processes involving the nucleus of the atom. 2 adjective Nuclear power is created by processes involving the nucleus of the atom.
noun The nucleus is the central part of an atom.
noun The nucleus of something is the central and most important part of it. The nucleus of her idea is good but some of the details aren't right.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See nuclear.

form.definition: adjective If someone is nude, they are not wearing any clothes. I like to sleep nude in summer. Nude bathing is permitted on this beach. 2 noun A nude is a picture of a person wearing no clothes. ... WORD FAMILYnoun nudity < >noun nudist
verb If you nudge someone, you give them a gentle poke or push, usually with your elbow. The girls nudged each other when the teacher came into the room. He nudged his way through the crowd.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun nudge Give me a nudge if I fall asleep.

form.definition: noun A nugget is a solid, generally small, lump of something. Digging near the old mine we found a nugget of gold.

noun A nuisance is someone or something that is irritating or annoying. My little sister can be a real nuisance. It was a terrible nuisance having to start all over again. 'There were all these forms to fill in.' 'What a nuisance!'
adjective If a part of your body is numb, it has no feeling in it. After the dentist gave me an injection, my mouth was numb for a couple of hours. My hands were numb with cold.
adjective If you feel numb with a certain emotion, such as grief or fear, you are unable to speak or act because of this emotion. She stood fixed to the spot, numb with fear.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun numbness < >verb numb This injection will numb your jaw.

form.definition: noun Numbers show how many things you are talking about. They are represented by words such as 'one', 'twenty' and 'thousand', and by symbols such as '2', '345' and '1 000 000'.

noun A number is a figure or a series of figures which identifies a place or a thing. I'm staying in room number 206. ...our neighbours at number16. What's your phone number? You have to key in your personal identification number. Two of number 37, please.
noun The number of something is its sum or total. The final number of deaths is likely to exceed 1000. It is hard to estimate the number of such cases.

noun A number of things or people means a collection of them, or several. I packed three books and a number of magazines. A number of people arrived late. There are still a number of things to do. He owns a large number of valuable first editions.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb number I numbered the pages from one to seventy.

form.definition: noun A numberplate is a metal plate attached to the front and back of your car, truck, motorbike or other vehicle, which displays its registration number. You'd better wash that mud off the numberplate. It's an offence to have the numbers covered.
noun A numeral is a symbol which represents a number, for example 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9 and 0.
noun The numerator of a fraction is the number that shows how many of the equally divided parts of the whole you are referring to. For example, in the fraction 7/8, the numerator is 7.
form.note: ... SEE ALSOdenominator.

form.definition: adjective If things are numerous, there are many of them. The document has been through numerous drafts. Over the years I've made numerous visits to Japan.
noun A nun is a woman who belongs to a religious order or group. Nuns generally live together in convents.
noun A nurse is someone trained to look after sick people, especially in hospital.
verb If you nurse someone, you look after them when they are ill. She's nursed her husband at home ever since he had his stroke.

verb If you nurse a baby, you hold it in your arms and look after it. He nursed the baby to sleep. Dozens of mothers, many nursing small children, besieged the council offices. Shall I nurse Sam for you while you get Daisy dressed?
verb You can also use nurse to mean feeding a baby at your breast. Some mothers nurse their babies for a couple of years.

noun A nursery is a place where young children are looked after. It may be a centre where mothers leave their children while they are shopping or at work. It may be the ward in a hospital where new babies sleep. It may be the baby's room at home. 2 noun A nursery is a place where young plants and trees are grown and sold.
noun A nut is the fruit which grows inside a hard shell on certain trees. We can eat many types of nuts.
noun A nut is a small piece of metal with a hole in it which is screwed onto[qrthe end of a bolt in order to hold it in place.
noun In informal language, if you call someone a nut, you mean that they are foolish or mad. Deryl's a bit of a nut, but he's a good mate.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective nutty (nuttier, nuttiest) ...another of Sean's nutty ideas. Most good programmers are a bit nutty.

form.definition: noun Nutrition is the way you get nourishment for your body from the different types of food that you eat. Good nutrition means good health. He's suffering from poor nutrition.

noun The nutrition in food is all the proteins, vitamins and minerals in it. His sole source of nutrition at the moment is Vegemite sandwiches! Junk food fills you up, but it doesn't contain much nutrition.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective nutritious You need a good nutritious breakfast to keep you going.< > adjective nutritional Such snacks are of little nutritional value.

form.definition: noun A nutritionist is someone who helps people to plan their diets so that they eat healthily.
abbreviation for north-west.
noun Nylon is a strong artificial fibre. It is used to make things such as fabric, rope and the bristles of brushes.[fa[xp
